artist: Jacob van der Heyden; Gerhard Alzenbach
creditline: Gift of Tom Rassieur in memory of Robert Bradford Wheaton
description: Skeleton holding arrows and spear surounded by skulls and broken objects; ten allegorical scenes with accompaning inscriptions
marks: On back written in pencil: [Dance of Death; rare]
provenance: Private collection, New York (until c. 1992; given to Rassieur in lieu of payment for consultation, c.1992); Tom Rassieur (c. 1992-2010; given to MIA)
text: Death looks quite cheerful today, and my mother would praise his posture. He holds three arrows labeled past, present, and future. In his right hand is a scythe. Above him a banderole bears a verse from Matthew 25: Watch ye, for ye know not the hour or the day when He shall come-a widely used passage in momento mori prints. He is surrounded on three sides by ten small vignettes depicting the process of maturing and aging.
title: The Ten Ages of Life (Die Zehn Lebensalter)
